title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

The thesis may appear anywhere within the response.

The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it neednâ€™t do so to earn the thesis point.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully conveys that line of reasoning.

Responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible position.

title: Part B: Evidence and Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Commentary explains the significance and relevance of evidence in relation to the line of reasoning.

Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

At this point in the course, students should have experience identifying evidence and developing commentary that supports a defensible position. In Unit 5, students should focus on developing the skills necessary to consistently provide specific evidence and explain how that evidence supports a line of reasoning. Active planning and reflection throughout the writing process can help students identify opportunities in their own work to further develop their thinking or enhance their arguments. Starting in Unit 7, students will be able to earn the sophistication point in Row C.
